conclusion: Analyze forces acting on the charged ball to determine motion.
Electric force acts horizontally to the right due to positive charge.
Ball moves in a straight line at angle θ opposite to electric field direction.
Net force must be zero in both horizontal and vertical directions for straight-line motion.
Resolve electric force into horizontal component qE and vertical component qE sin θ.
Resolve gravitational force into horizontal component mg cos θ and vertical component -mg sin θ.
Set up equation for horizontal net force: qE + mg cos θ = 0.
Set up equation for vertical net force: qE sin θ - mg sin θ = 0.
From vertical force equation, deduce qE = mg.
Calculate work done by electric force using change in electric potential energy: ΔU = q(V - V0).
Relate work done to electric field: WE = qE d cos φ.
Since ball moves at angle θ opposite to electric field, φ = π + θ, thus WE = -qE d cos θ.
Using qE = mg, deduce WE = -mg d cos θ.
Equate expressions for work done: mg d cos θ = q(V - V0).
Since qE = mg, deduce d cos θ = V - V0.
Substitute d cos θ = V - V0 into work done expression: WE = -mg (V - V0).
Calculate change in electric potential energy: ΔU = mg (V - V0).
Difference in electric potential energy at highest point compared to point O is mg (V - V0).
